IRE240H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE240H1-F-20189.courseDescription: An introduction to the study of the world of work and employment, the history and development of employment relations, its central theories and concepts; the behaviours, outcomes, practices and institutions that emerge from or affect the employment relationship; contemporary issues and comparative employment relations systems.
IRE240H1-F-20189.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASSPE/ASMAJ1535) or 4.0 FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3.

IRE242H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE242H1-F-20189.courseTitle: HRM for Industrial Relations and HR Professionals
IRE242H1-F-20189.courseDescription: This course explores the relationship between human resource management, employment relations, and industrial relations. Extensive practical course work will expose students to the functions human resource professionals execute to recruit, select, compensate, train, and evaluate the performance of employees. The course prepares students for advanced HR topics in upper level IRE courses. Note: Course will not count towards Rotman Commerce program requirements.
IRE242H1-F-20189.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASMAJ1535, ASSPE1535)

IRE244H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE244H1-F-20189.courseDescription: Introduction to the institutions, issues and legislation affecting the employment relationship in the public and private sectors in Canada, with emphasis on collective bargaining. The economic and political environment, history of the labour movement, union organization, certification, contract negotiation, strikes, dispute resolution, contract administration and grievances.
IRE244H1-F-20189.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASSPE1535/ASMAJ1535) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3.

IRE260H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE260H1-F-20189.courseDescription: Introduction to the nature of organizations and the behaviour of individuals and groups within organizations, including topics such as culture and diversity, reward systems, motivation, leadership, politics, communication, decision-making, conflict and group processes. Not recommended for students in Commerce programs.
IRE260H1-F-20189.prerequisite: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASSPE1535/ASMAJ1535) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3

IRE339H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE339H1-F-20189.courseDescription:
This course is designed to provide students in the Employment Relations program with knowledge of how the labour market affects the employment relationship. The basic tools of labour economics are developed and applied to various issues of organizational and government policy such as: the incentive effects of compensation arrangements, government income support programs, and minimum wage policy; the determinants of preferences for hours of work including job-sharing, overtime and retirement; the impacts of unions on compensation and productivity; public-sector employment and alternatives to the right to strike; discrimination in employment on the basis of gender and race as well as related government policies such as pay and employment equity.
Note: IRE339H1 will not count towards an ECO program.

IRE342H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE342H1-S-20189.courseTitle: Finance and Accounting for HR/IR Professionals
IRE342H1-S-20189.courseDescription: This course introduces Employment Relations students to accounting and finance procedures and concepts used by Human Resources managers and Industrial Relations experts in organizations such as government, trade unions and companies. The course covers both managerial and financial accounting with an applied focus to the employment relations function within organizations. It is geared specifically to students who aspire to become HR/Labour Relations professionals where essential knowledge in finance and accounting is required. Note: Course will not count towards Rotman Commerce program requirements.

IRE346H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE346H1-S-20189.courseDescription: An understanding is developed of how essential elements of the human resource planning process support organizational goals and strategies. Topics such as environmental influences, job analysis, forecasting human resource needs and ascertaining supply, succession planning, downsizing and restructuring, mergers and acquisitions, outsourcing, and strategic international issues are examined.

IRE347H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE347H1-S-20189.courseDescription: The role of training and development initiatives in organizations. Students acquire the knowledge and skills to conduct a training needs assessment, identify training objectives, explore strategies to increase the transfer of training, design and deliver a training activity using various training methodologies, and evaluate its effectiveness.

IRE348H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE348H1-F-20189.courseDescription: The principles, legal issues, and emerging trends affecting the recruitment process and selection of staff in organizations.  Development of recruitment strategies, assessment of applications for employment, interviewing candidates, and the role of testing and measurement of competencies in making hiring decisions.

IRE367H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE367H1-F-20189.courseDescription: The theory and process of developing and administering compensation systems. Through the core compensation principles of efficiency, equity, consistency and competitiveness we consider such topics as: job analysis, job evaluation, pay levels and structures, pay for performance, benefits, and compensating special groups of workers.

IRE378H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE378H1-S-20189.courseDescription: The influence of legislation, the labour market and collective bargaining on health policies and programs in the workplace. The rights and responsibilities of employers, employees, unions and governments for the regulation and promotion of workplace health and safety; and the implications of evolving demographic, economic, and social factors.

IRE379H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE379H1-S-20189.courseTitle: Employment Relations Research & Human Resource Analytics
IRE379H1-S-20189.courseDescription: An introduction to fundamental quantitative and qualitative research methods to enable students to critically evaluate and conduct research in the labour field. The class will explore data-driven, analytical approaches to managing human resources using basic metrics, analysis, and interpretation of information that link human resource initiatives to various indicators of organizational performance.

IRE430H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE430H1-F-20189.courseTitle: Canadian Employment Law & the Non-Union Workplace
IRE430H1-F-20189.courseDescription: The course will focus on the law governing employment in a non-unionized workplace. Specifically, it will cover every phase of the employment relationship from hiring to termination and beyond and the rights and obligations of employers and employees as developed by the Courts and under employment-related statutes (namely the <u>Employment Standards Act, 2000</u> and the <u>Human Rights Code</u>.) The course will also cover provisions from the <u>Occupational Health and Safety Act</u>.

IRE431H1-S-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE431H1-S-20189.courseTitle: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace
IRE431H1-S-20189.courseDescription: The course will focus on the laws impacting unionized workplaces. It will cover every phase of the Ontario Labour Relations Act, 1995 (the “LRA”) from union organizing, certification, negotiation and bargaining, collective agreement arbitration, retention of bargaining rights and decertification and termination of bargaining rights.

IRE472H1-F-20189.orgName: Industrial Relations and Human Resources, Centre for (IRE)
IRE472H1-F-20189.courseDescription: Resolving conflicts constructively is a challenge faced by all organizations and most individuals. This course will cover fundamentals of the negotiation process and conflict resolution. This course will apply multiple cases and simulations providing students with several opportunities to build their skills.
IRE472H1-F-20189.prerequisite: IRE244H1, IRE260H1 and 1 300H level IRE course
